channel.name: Is it possible to proof.verify() within a circuit with a return value?

messages.content: I want to call `const valid: Bool = proof.verify()`, is that possible? the current api returns `void` from verify.
cc @gregor
Not possible with the current system
is this going to be possible with Kimchi eventually?
Pickles is the place where we'd need to implement it. I imagine it wouldn't be very hard. What's the use case?

i have a circuitA -> proofA, circuitA takes proofB as private input and verifies it. 

i want to be able to generate a valid proofA, even if proofB isnt valid.

I only now realize that i wont even be able to run circuitA unless i have a already valid proofB at hand. So the API isn’t an issue then. cc @rpanic

Fwiw we do have a way to conditionally verify. 'proof.verifyIf(bool)'
It's less powerful than a boolean return would be but it does support the use case of "either the proof has to be valid or this other condition needs to hold"

embeds.title: Mina Documentation
embeds.description: Website for documentation about Mina Protocol

embeds.title: snarky/snarkette/groth16.ml at fa2cb9be5f61b93d5892bd7c838a0ff230d8...
embeds.description: OCaml DSL for verifiable computation. Contribute to o1-labs/snarky development by creating an account on GitHub.

messages.content: yes, that works. but its not a part of a circuit, so unfortunately not applicable to my case

I'm not sure I understand your concern. Can't you do that verification inside of the method? If you need to store a commitment for that proof, you can use its hash in state vars or a merkle root, if you'd like to to store all of the used proof in a more organized data structure.
within a method/circuit you can only do provable operations/code. arbitrary JS code like the non-provable verify, or try/catch wont work
last statement here sums it up

> within a method/circuit you can only do provable operations/code. arbitrary JS code like the non-provable verify, or try/catch wont work

Thank you. It looks like this is something that I missed from the docs. Do you happen to have a resource at hand where I can read more about this?
mmm not really any i’m aware of, afaik all snarky bindings like UInt, Field, Struct, asserts, add, etc are part of the provable code

> I only now realize that i wont even be able to run circuitA unless i have a already valid proofB at hand. So the API isn’t an issue then.
Well, the proof could be valid or invalid. You can pass an invalid proof as an argument. Let's say you read some state variables, and the GraphQL API returned you outdated values due to an issue in it. When the verifier performs the state variable assertions, it will reject it
given our other convo about circuit development, the circuit must be a static non changing trace of computation, so a try catch or js if statement breaks that
invalid proof doesnt even exist afaik, mock proofs do cc @gregor
the case you described is still a valid proof, but has preconditions attached to it via AUs

> given our other convo about circuit development, the circuit must be a static non changing trace of computation, so a try catch or js if statement breaks that
Can't you use `Circuit.if()` ?
yes but not a native js if

Wouldn't this work?

```
const ok = Circuit.if(verify(proof.toJSON(), verificationKey), true, false);
```
and with Circuit.if, all the code is evaluated for all cases, just a different return value is then used but also the ‘else’ statement runs
P.S. I'm just diving deep into recursion, verificaiton and more complex logic now.
no, verify that you used isnt provable
proof.verify() is
Oh, so these are different verifies
I understand, thank you.
circuit if just alternates between two values but it does not conditionally run code

> and with Circuit.if, all the code is evaluated for all cases, just a different return value is then used but also the ‘else’ statement runs
So your challenge is to execute code conditionally. If the proof is valid, you want to run A, else you want to run B. Is my understanding correct?
no, i just wanted to get a boolean status of the verification in a provable way, but then i realised as long as i’m able to construct the proof it will be valid

in more detail, i wanted to verify a proof and use the boolean status of the verification in the circuit for additional computation. but as far as i understand if the proof isnt valid i shouldnt be able to run the circuit at all
I don't believe this is the case. Pretty sure any circuit can be reworked to use verifyIf.
if you depend on the return, have private input that is the supposed result of evaluating it, pass it to verifyIf, but you can't see whether it _failed_
you can't check whether a proof is invalid
is this that important anyway?
the main motivation here was to find out if you can run a circuit with an invalid proof as a param
i don’t think thats doable, the circuit wont run at all right @gregor
wdym run

literally myZkProgram.myMethod(myProof)

where myProof must be valid otherwise myMethod wont generate a valid proof at all
which is ok, i thought i might have a case where i can run the code above using a malformed proof and it’d still work.. or something. which is obviously majorly flawed thinking on my side
Sure why wouldn't you be able to "run the circuit" if the proof isn't valid?
Use verifyIf and pass a dummy proof
i’ll have a think about this again in the morning, thanks
